summary: LinkedIn is among major tech companies that have slashed their workforces this year . The Microsoft-owned tech company has cut 281 workers in California, a notice filed this week shows . Microsoft said earlier this month that it was terminating 3% of staff, or about 6,000 workers .  LinkedIn's California layoffs affected workers at its offices in San Francisco, Mountain View, Carpinteria and Sunnyvale . More than half of those cuts hit its workforce in Mountain View . The company didn't respond to a request for comment .  LinkedIn laid off nearly 700 employees in 2023 . Microsoft purchased LinkedIn for $26 billion in 2016 . In April, the company reported that its revenue in the third fiscal year quarter reached $4.3 billion .
Tech stocks were in the red late Friday afternoon, with the Technology Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLK) in red . Tech stocks in red late on Friday afternoon .

Microsoft shares have added about 7.8% in a month since its last earnings report . Estimates have been trending upward for the stock . Microsoft has a nice Growth Score of B, but is lagging a lot on the Momentum Score front with a D .  Microsoft has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) We expect an in-line return from the stock in the next few months . The magnitude of these revisions looks promising .

Apple could be heavily impacted by tariffs, but the long-term investment thesis is sound . Microsoft continues to fire on all cylinders and deserves to be near an all-time high . Visa and American Express benefit from network effects that help them steadily grow over time .  Apple assembles the vast majority of key products, like iPhones, in China . President Trump has cast Apple onto the front lines of the trade war with China, with the latest decision being a 25% tariff on iPhones not made in the U.S.  Apple may just have to absorb the tariff hit and hope resolutions come soon or pass along a portion of the costs to consumers . The good news is that Apple has highly anticipated products with AI features coming this fall which may be enough to pique consumer interest and justify higher price tags .  Visa has a simpler business model and is arguably lower risk and lower reward than American Express . It is a pure-play payment processor that collects fees based on the frequency and volume of transactions on its credit and debit cards . The more cards engaged with the network, the more potential Visa has for collecting fees .  American Express is so profitable that it converts around two-thirds of every dollar in sales into operating income . Visa's expenses mainly go toward maintaining its network, American Express spends more on card member rewards than on operating expenses . American Express attracts affluent customers due to the high annual fees on its cards .  Apple, Microsoft, Visa, and American Express have seen their stock prices grow rapidly . As a result, their dividend yields have compressed even though all four companies consistently boost their payouts year after year . All four companies regularly repurchase stock, meaning that the dividend isn't the only means of returning capital to shareholders . Tevogen.AI™ aims to integrate advanced machine learning and predictive modeling into its proprietary ExacTcell™ technology to significantly enhance its target identification and pre-clinical processes, thereby strengthening the Company’s pipeline of innovative immunotherapies . The Company plans to expand its AI initiative with applications that extend well beyond Tevgen Bio .  Tevogen.AI’s vision extends beyond transforming how therapies are developed; it is expected to make a meaningful impact across multiple sectors of healthcare . Microsoft (Nasdaq:MSFT):Provides industry-leading AI expertise, cloud computing infrastructure (Azure), and scientific resources to accelerate drug discovery processes .  The PredicTcell platform is a collection of multiple algorithms which performs in-silico predictions for candidate selection across multiple diseases . Tevogen.AI has developed a continually expanding, terabyte-scale database that processes millions of protein and peptide interactions spanning numerous diseases .  Tevogen.AI plans to expand into clinical trial patient identification using the information collected from its PredicTcell and AdapTcell platforms . The platform aims to expand upon the cross sections of genetics and protein interactions and build an HLA specificity map . One of Microsoft Corp's subsidiaries in Russia plans to file for bankruptcy . President Vladimir Putin said this week that foreign service providers like Microsoft and Zoom should be "throttled" in Russia to make way for domestic software solutions . Microsoft continued providing key services in Russia after Moscow's February 2022 invasion of Ukraine .  Microsoft has three other Russian units - Microsoft Development Centre Rus, Microsoft Mobile Rus and Microsoft Payments Rus . Google's Russian subsidiary filed for bankruptcy in 2022, saying seizure of its bank account made it untenable for its Russian office to function .

IonQ andMicrosoft Corporation MSFT are making waves in the emerging field of quantum computing . IonQ is a pure-play quantum computing pioneer, focused solely on developing cutting-edge quantum computers and networks . Microsoft is a tech giant weaving quantum technology into its massive Azure cloud platform .  In first-quarter 2025, the company secured its first commercial sale, a $22 million deal with EPB, a utility in Tennessee, to deploy its Forte Enterprise quantum computer and quantum network . IonQ is aggressively expanding its reach through strategic partnerships and acquisitions .  For 2025, IonQ forecasts revenue between $75 million and $95 million – roughly 97% growth . IonQ is also building out a full-stack quantum ecosystem . The U.S. government has recognized IonQ’s capabilities .  In first-quarter 2025, IonQ’s net loss was $32.3 million (narrower than a year ago due to some one-time gains), and its adjusted EBITDA loss actually widened as operating expenses jumped 38% year over year . The quantum computing sector is highly competitive .  Microsoft is one of the world’s most valuable companies, with a dominant position in enterprise software and cloud computing . Unlike IonQ, Microsoft benefits from significant profitability and a broad economic moat across multiple tech sectors . Its Azure cloud platform is pivotal to its quantum strategy, providing access to a range of quantum hardware .  Microsoft unveiled its Majorana 1 quantum processing chip in early 2025 . Microsoft has $80 billion in cash reserves to continue investing in quantum initiatives . Microsoft is primed to capitalize on quantum advancements, offering quantum computing-as-a-service when the technology matures .  Microsoft's quantum hardware progress lags behind competitors like IBM, which has built over 100 qubit superconducting processors . IonQ has recently garnered attention with a significant 57.8% surge in its stock price over the past month, despite a modest 3.4% year-to-date gain .  Microsoft has been pacing the broader tech rally, whereas IonQ’s surge was an outlier . The Zacks Computer and Technology sector has gained 8.3% in the past month but declined 1.7% YTD . Valuation remains a key concern for IonQ, with a forward 12-month price-to-sales ratio of 91.76 .  IonQ’s premium valuation is heavily dependent on its ability to execute its strategy and secure a leading position in the emerging quantum market before its competitors . Microsoft trades at about 10.99X, far below IONQ but above the sector, but much lower than that of IonQ .  IonQ and Microsoft each represent compelling but distinct plays in the quantum cloud space . IonQ is a high-risk, high-reward investment with impressive growth prospects . Microsoft offers a more stable investment with a dominant presence in the cloud and AI sectors backed by a robust financial position .  IonQ is the stock with greater upside potential right now . Its Zacks Rank of 3 (Hold) position it as a more conservative investment . For those willing to tolerate volatility in exchange for the chance of significant gains .

The Vanguard Information Technology Index Fund and the Vanguard Growth Index Fund have produced some fantastic returns for investors in the past five years . Both offer broad diversification, holding well over 100 stocks in their portfolios . As is usual at Vanguard, both funds charge incredibly low fees to investors .  The S&P 500's total returns (which include dividends) are 109% over the past five years . Given the strong trends in AI and investments that continue to flow into AI-related projects, this ETF can still be an excellent option for your portfolio .  The Vanguard Information Technology Index Fund can be an excellent long-term investment . Most of the stocks in the fund account for no more than 4% of its total holdings, with the exception being the big three:Apple,Microsoft, and Nvidia . For a more balanced option outside of tech, you may want to consider the Vanguard Growth Index Fund .  The same top three stocks that make up the bulk of the Vanguard tech fund are also the top three in this ETF . The more diversified Vanguard Growth Index Fund, which charges a lower expense ratio of 0.04%, can be a better option for more . Microsoft(MSFT) has been one of the most searched-for stocks on Zacks.com lately . Over the past month, shares of this software maker have returned +7.8%, compared to the Zacks S&P 500 composite's +6.4% change . The key question is: What could be the stock's future direction?  Microsoft is expected to post earnings of $3.35 per share for the current quarter, representing a year-over-year change of +13.6%. Over the last 30 days, the Zacks Consensus Estimate has changed +2%. The consensus earnings estimate for the next fiscal year of $14.89 indicates a change of -11.7% from what Microsoft expects .  Microsoft is rated Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) due to the size of the recent change in the consensus estimate, along with three other factors related to earnings estimates . Over the past month, the estimate for the current quarter of $73.71 has changed +2% .  Microsoft reported revenues of $70.07 billion in the last reported quarter, representing a year-over-year change of +13.3% . The company beat consensus estimates in each of the trailing four quarters . Microsoft topped consensus revenue estimates each time over this period .  The Zacks Value Style Score organizes stocks into five groups ranging from A to F . Microsoft is graded D on this front, indicating that it is trading at a premium to its peers . The facts discussed here and much other information on Zacks.com might help determine whether or not it's worthwhile .  Microsoft's Zacks Rank #3 does suggest that it may perform in line with the broader market in the near term . paying attention to the market buzz about Microsoft may be paying attention .

Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) has struck a deal to supply Barclays (NYSE:BCS) with 100,000licenses for its Copilot AI assistants . Barclays will implement Copilot across its workforce to streamline workflows, automate tasks and enhance decision-making . The bank's move signals a shift toward AI-driven efficiency in banking services .  Copilot aims to make Copilot integral to corporate operations worldwide . At $30 per user per month, these agreements could yield tens of millions annually .

The global Artificial Intelligence (AI) market is set for a significant transformation, with its value projected to soar from USD 371.71 billion in 2025 to USD 2,407.02 billion by 2032 . Rise of AI-as-a-Service (AIaaS) platforms is democratizing AI access, allowing businesses of all sizes to implement AI technologies without requiring deep expertise .  Microsoft closed at $458.68 up 0.3%, near its 52-week high. Meanwhile,Jingbo Technologylagged, down 24.2% to end the day at $9.00. Microsoft announced a major deal with Barclays for 100,000 Copilot AI licenses . The investment legend loves companies that don't require a lot of capital investment . But he has invested in some very capital-intensive "Magnificent Seven" companies . Most have been capital-light for many years, but that might be changing .  Many questions are posed to Buffett at the annual meeting -- from shareholders present and from business journalist Becky Quick . Buffett: Many such companies are now deploying a lot of capital to pursue AI-related goals .  Buffett favors capital-light businesses such as Coca-Cola as a "fabulous" kind of business . The "Magnificent Seven" stocks are Apple, Amazon.com, Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia, andTesla. Buffett acknowledges that things can change over time .  Buffett has built Berkshire Hathaway into an interesting mix of capital-light and capital-intensive businesses . Buffett has also built the company into See's Candies, International Dairy Queen and the Business Wire press release platform . The companies listed here are all strong U.S.-based businesses with excellent fundamentals . Their tariff risks seem relatively low compared to other stocks . Walmart, which is based in Bentonville, Arkansas, has a lot of power with vendors to influence prices .  CFO: "The magnitude of these increases is more than any retailer can absorb" Walmart's sales rose by 2.5% year over year, to $165.6 billion . The company was able to pass along rising costs amid inflation and it says it needs to do so again now .  Home Depot is another retailer which may perform better than most this year . Unlike Walmart, it doesn't anticipate raising prices as a result of tariffs . The Atlanta-based retailer doesn't expect any country outside the U.S. to account for more than 10% of its purchases in the year ahead .  Microsoft's revenue rose by 15% (when excluding the impact of foreign exchange) to just over $70 billion . Microsoft posted double-digit growth in most categories, including Azure and other cloud services . At a P/E of 35, Microsoft isn't a terribly cheap stock to buy but given its diversification .  Walmart has generated nearly $97 billion in profit over the past four quarters . The Motley Fool's total average return is978% -- a market-crushing outperformance compared to170% for the S&P 500 . Walmart isn't one of the best growth stocks to buy today .  The Motley Fool recommends Home Depot, Microsoft, and Walmart . Home Depot is one of the top 10 companies in the U.S. stock market . Microsoft is the second-largest retailer in the world .

Chase Coleman's Tiger Global Management fund made some major purchases of top artificial intelligence (AI) stocks during the first quarter . If a fund has over $100 million in assets, it is required to divulge its end-of-quarter holdings to the SEC .  During the first quarter, Tiger Global Management purchased a few big-time AI stocks . These included Microsoft, Amazon, Nvidia, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing . All four of these stocks were already in the fund's portfolio prior to Q1 .  Taiwan Semiconductor stock can be purchased for under 21 times forward earnings . This is a lower-than-market multiple, yet Taiwan Semi is expected to deliver monster growth over the next five years . Management believes its AI-related revenue can increase at a 45% compound annual growth rate (CAGR)  Wall Street analysts expect 53% revenue growth in fiscal year 2026 (ending January 2026) and 24% next year . Amazon isn't a revenue growth story; it's a margin expansion story . Microsoft is expected to grow revenue at a 14% and 13% pace in 2025 and 2026 .  While Microsoft has proven to be a strong and resilient business over the past few years, I don't think I'd want to own the stock as much as the other three . It's just as expensive as Amazon and Nvidia, yet it doesn't have quite the growth upside to justify the cost . Microsoft isn't abadAI stock to own, but it's at the bottom of my list for the four AI stocks Tiger Global Management bought this quarter . The S&P 500 was down by as much as 19% from its all-time high after President Trump announced his "Liberation Day" tariffs on April 2 . The index has erased those losses since then because several countries have come to the table to negotiate new trade deals .  The Vanguard Information Technology ETF outperformed the S&P 500 every year, on average, since it was established in 2004 . It currently holds 307 stocks spread across 12 subsegments of the sector . The semiconductor segment has the largest segment in the index by far, representing 31.7% of its total market capitalization .  Nvidia, Broadcom, Microsoft, Apple, Salesforce, Palantir, Oracle, ServiceNow, and Salesforce all feature in the Vanguard ETF .  Salesforce developed the world's most popular customer relationship management platform . Palantir developed a series of AI-powered software platforms like Foundry, Gotham, and AIP . Oracle is building some of the most advanced and cost-efficient data centers in the world for developing AI models .  Micron, on the other hand, makes memory and storage chips, which are increasingly important for processing AI workloads . The Vanguard Information Technology ETF delivered a compound annual return of 12.8% since it was established in 2004 .  Young investors who can afford to take some risk might benefit from a larger allocation to this high-growth segment of the market, especially as megatrends like AI unfold . An investor who placed $50,000 in the S&P 500 in 2004 would be sitting on $342,761 today . Tesla's electric vehicle sales are plummeting, and continued weakness could lead to massive losses for the stock . CEO Elon Musk believes self-driving cars and humanoid robots will eventually make Tesla the world's most valuable company one day . Today, those five companies areMicrosoft,Apple,Nvidia,Amazon, and Alphabet, and they have a combined market capitalization of $13.6 trillion .  Tesla is seeing plummeting demand for electric vehicles . Most of its revenue still comes from selling electric vehicles (EVs) Tesla can't grow production 50% per year if sales aren't keeping up . Deliveries plunged even further in the first quarter of 2025 .  Analyst estimates indicate Tesla might deliver as little as 350,000 cars during the second quarter, or a year-over-year drop of more than 20% . EV sales overall soared 28% across Europe in April . Chinese automakerBYDsaw 359% increase in sales across the region .  Last October, Tesla unveiled its long-awaited Cybercab robotaxi . It has no pedals or steering wheel because it's designed to run entirely on the company's Full Self-Driving (FSD) software . The unsupervised version of Tesla's FSD isn't approved for use on public roads yet .  Tesla CEO Musk says the company could generate $10 trillion in revenue over the long term . The company could be producing millions of robots annually by 2029 or 2030 . The Optimus robot could be used for dangerous jobs and repetitive tasks that humans don't want to do .  Tesla's stock is trading at an eyewatering price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 186.5 . Nvidia, Microsoft, Amazon, Apple, and Alphabet trade at an average P/E ratio of just 32.2: Tesla's earnings per share (EPS)plunged 71% during the first quarter of 2025 .  Tesla is destined for a sharp decline instead, bringing its P/E ratio in line with those of its big-tech peers . As a result, there is little hope the company will grow to exceed the combined value of Nvidia, Microsoft, Amazon, Apple and Alphabet anytime soon .  Right now, we’re issuing ‘Double Down’ alerts for three incredible companies, available when you joinStock Advisor, and there may not be another chance like this anytime soon . If you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2004,you’d have $651,761!  Could Send Its Stock Plunging by 70% instead of plummeting by more than 70% . The Motley Fool has more than 1,000 shares of stock in its portfolio .

Appaloosa's billionaire chief David Tepper completely exited or substantially reduced his fund's stakes in five brand-name artificial intelligence (AI) stocks in the March-ended quarter . The deadline for institutional investors overseeing at least $100 million to fileForm 13F with the Securities and Exchange Commission was May 15 .  David Tepper of Appaloosa Management traded 130,000 shares in AI-networking specialistBroadcom . Tepper's net-selling of artificial intelligence stocks was his first-quarter trading activity . As of the end of March, Tepper oversaw close to $8.4 billion in assets under management .  Based on Appaloosa's 13F, Tepper sold shares of five prominent artificial intelligence stocks in the March-ended quarter . It's quite possible this selling activity represents nothing more than simple profit-taking . Shares of Nvidia, Microsoft, AMD, Lam Research have all rocketed higher as the AI revolution has taken shape .  The worry is that there may be more than just benign profit-taking and/or stop losses (in Intel's case) behind Tepper's aggressive net selling of AI stocks . On one hand, demand for AI-graphics processing units (GPUs) and AI solutions has been exceptionally strong . Nvidia's Hopper (H100) and Blackwell GPUs hold a seemingly insurmountable market share lead in AI-accelerated data centers . Intel's central processing units are also playing a role in the expansion of AI-data center infrastructure .  Many of Nvidia's largest customers are internally developing AI chips to use in their data centers . This is expected to weigh on Nvidia's pricing power, as well as AMD and possibly even Intel . It also has the potential to adversely impact the pricing power for semiconductor equipment companies like Lam Research .  If the AI bubble were to burst, we'd see widespread weakness among the five prominent AI stocks Tepper completely exited or reduced in the March-ended quarter . Every game-changing technology needs time to mature, and AI isn't anywhere close to having reached the point of maturity .  David Tepper may be allowing these odds to partially guide his investment strategy . The Motley Fool Stock Advisoranalyst team just identified what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy now… and Nvidia wasn’t one of them .
